title: About
text:
I’m Dhruv Garg, a Data Scientist with 3 years of hands-on industry experience and currently pursuing my Master of Data Science at the University of British Columbia. I specialize in designing and deploying machine learning solutions that deliver measurable business value — particularly in marketing analytics and performance optimization.
Previously, I’ve worked with startups and IT consultancies across North America, leading initiatives in large-scale data processing, LLM evaluation, marketing attribution modeling, and cloud-based ETL pipelines. My work has led to improved ROI, reduced infrastructure costs, and streamlined analytics workflows.
In addition to professional roles, I’ve developed open-source packages and interactive dashboards as part of my academic projects, using tools like Dash, Docker, Quarto, and PySpark.
I’m passionate about building intelligent systems that are both scalable and human-centered — and always open to collaborating on impactful data projects.

title: 🛒 RetailPulse: Online Retail Analytics Dashboard
text:
Retail operations managers face challenges in managing inventory, tracking sales trends, and identifying market expansion opportunities. Making informed decisions swiftly is crucial to staying competitive.
RetailPulse was created to bridge this gap by providing an interactive, data-driven dashboard 📊 that enables retailers to gain real-time insights into their business performance.

title: 🛒 RetailPulse: Online Retail Analytics Dashboard
text:
Retail operations managers face challenges in managing inventory, tracking sales trends, and identifying market expansion opportunities. Making informed decisions swiftly is crucial to staying competitive.
RetailPulse was created to bridge this gap by providing an interactive, data-driven dashboard 📊 that enables retailers to gain real-time insights into their business performance.

title: 🛒 RetailPulse: Online Retail Analytics Dashboard
text:
📂 Data Attribution
This project uses data from the Online Retail Dataset available on UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository.

title: 🛒 RetailPulse: Online Retail Analytics Dashboard
text:
🚀 Features

📈 Monitor sales trends over time with interactive charts

🔄 Analyze customer retention and repeat purchasing behavior

🌍 Visualize regional sales with maps

📦 Evaluate product performance using bar charts and word clouds




RetailPulse Demo

title: 🛒 RetailPulse: Online Retail Analytics Dashboard
text:
🛠 Running the App Locally
git clone https://github.com/UBC-MDS/DSCI-532_2025_15_RetailPulse.git
cd DSCI-532_2025_15_RetailPulse
conda env create -f environment.yaml
conda activate retailpulse
python src/app.py

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
📦 About the Package
num_theory is a high-performance Python package designed to streamline solving number theory problems — especially those found on Project Euler. It offers:

Fast prime number generation
Primality tests
Prime factorization
Arithmetic progression tools
Intuitive, simple API design

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
🧪 Installation
pip install num_theory_euler_problems

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
🔧 Core Features

🧮 get_primes(n) — Generate all primes less than n
🔍 is_prime(n) — Efficient primality testing
🧠 prime_factorization(n) — Return prime factors with powers
➕ arithmetic_progression(a, d, n) — Compute terms, sum, or nth term in AP

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
🧑‍💻 Usage Examples
from num_theory import get_primes, is_prime, prime_factorization

get_primes(10)           # [2, 3, 5, 7]
is_prime(17)             # True
prime_factorization(84)  # [(2, 2), (3, 1), (7, 1)]

Real-Life Example: Monthly Savings
from num_theory import arithmetic_progression

# Save $50, increasing by $20 each month
arithmetic_progression(a=50, d=20, n=6)               # [50, 70, 90, 110, 130, 150]
arithmetic_progression(a=50, d=20, n=6, compute_sum=True)  # 600.0
arithmetic_progression(a=50, d=20, n=6, nth_term=True)     # 150

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
🧠 Euler Problem Examples

Problem 3: Largest Prime Factor
from num_theory import prime_factorization

factors = prime_factorization(600851475143)
largest_prime = factors[-1][0]
print(largest_prime)  # Output: 6857


Problem 10: Sum of Primes Below Two Million
from num_theory import get_primes

primes = get_primes(2_000_000)
print(sum(primes))  # Output: 142913828922

title: 🔢 num_theory: Number Theory Utilities for Project Euler
text:
🥇 Why Use num_theory?

⚡ Optimized for large computations
🧩 Consolidated utility functions
🧪 Speed + Simplicity
📚 Project Euler–focused

title: 🚔 Vancouver Crime Statistics Dashboard
text:
Crime statistics provide valuable insights into public safety and law enforcement effectiveness. This dashboard is designed for policymakers, researchers, and local authorities to analyze crime trends across Vancouver neighborhoods.
Using the dashboard, users can:

📈 Track crime trends over time

🏘️ Compare crime types across neighborhoods

📆 Analyze monthly crime patterns

🔍 Filter data by date, location, and type

title: 🚔 Vancouver Crime Statistics Dashboard
text:
Crime statistics provide valuable insights into public safety and law enforcement effectiveness. This dashboard is designed for policymakers, researchers, and local authorities to analyze crime trends across Vancouver neighborhoods.
Using the dashboard, users can:

📈 Track crime trends over time

🏘️ Compare crime types across neighborhoods

📆 Analyze monthly crime patterns

🔍 Filter data by date, location, and type

title: 🚔 Vancouver Crime Statistics Dashboard
text:
🖥️ App Overview
Built with Shiny in R, this dashboard provides an interactive interface for visualizing Vancouver crime data.

Features

🗺️ Neighborhood Selection – choose one or more
🔍 Crime Type Filtering – drill down to specific crimes
📅 Date Range Selection – select time windows
📊 Dynamic Plot Selection – line/bar charts toggle
🔥 Heatmap – monthly crime distribution
📋 Interactive Data Table – full searchable table

title: 🚔 Vancouver Crime Statistics Dashboard
text:
⚙️ Installation & Setup

1️⃣ Clone the Repository
git clone git@github.ubc.ca:mds-2024-25/DSCI_532_individual-assignment_dgarg001.git
cd DSCI_532_individual-assignment_dgarg001


2️⃣ Set Up R Environment
install.packages("renv")
renv::restore()
This will install all dependencies using renv.lock.


3️⃣ Run the App
Option A – Inside R:
shiny::runApp('src')
Option B – From terminal:
cd src
Rscript -e "shiny::runApp()"

title: 🚔 Vancouver Crime Statistics Dashboard
text:
🎥 Demo
A walkthrough of the dashboard is available here:
📽️ demo.mp4

title: 🚲 Seoul Bike Share Predictor
text:
In this project, we aimed to build a Docker image from scratch and create a fully reproducible analysis pipeline for future use.
The primary goal was to learn and practice key software engineering tools, including:

Setting up Docker images
Implementing a CI/CD pipeline
Managing environments using Conda
Using make commands for workflow automation
Documenting the project using Quarto

We chose a simple dataset for this project, as the main focus was on understanding software tools rather than complex data modeling.



Rental bikes enhance urban mobility, but predicting their demand is crucial to maintaining a stable supply.
This project uses historical bike rental counts, weather information, and holiday data to forecast hourly bike demand in Seoul.
The dataset was sourced from the UCI Machine Learning Repository and described in studies by Sathishkumar V E, Jangwoo Park, and Yongyun Cho.

title: 🚲 Seoul Bike Share Predictor
text:
In this project, we aimed to build a Docker image from scratch and create a fully reproducible analysis pipeline for future use.
The primary goal was to learn and practice key software engineering tools, including:

Setting up Docker images
Implementing a CI/CD pipeline
Managing environments using Conda
Using make commands for workflow automation
Documenting the project using Quarto

We chose a simple dataset for this project, as the main focus was on understanding software tools rather than complex data modeling.



Rental bikes enhance urban mobility, but predicting their demand is crucial to maintaining a stable supply.
This project uses historical bike rental counts, weather information, and holiday data to forecast hourly bike demand in Seoul.
The dataset was sourced from the UCI Machine Learning Repository and described in studies by Sathishkumar V E, Jangwoo Park, and Yongyun Cho.

title: 🚲 Seoul Bike Share Predictor
text:
📈 Project Features

🔍 Predicts hourly rental demand based on weather and calendar variables
📦 Fully Dockerized environment for reproducible analysis
🛠 Automated workflows using Makefile commands
📊 Comprehensive EDA, model fitting, and evaluation
📝 Detailed project documentation created using Quarto
